|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120913221523/http://www.ign.com/top/rpgs/69 |archivedate=September 13, 2012 |df=}} ==Legacy== ===''Persona 3 FES''=== {{nihongo|''Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 3 FES''|ペルソナ3フェス|Perusona Surī Fesu}} is an add-on disc for ''Persona 3'' containing updates to the original game, as well as a new [[epilogue]] in which the player controls [[List of Persona 3 characters#Aigis|Aigis]]. ''FES'' was released in Japan on April 19, 2007, as both a stand-alone game, and with the "director's cut" version of ''Persona 3''. Overseas, the combined edition was published in North America by [[Atlus#Atlus USA|Atlus U.S.A.]] on April 22, 2008, and in Europe by [[Koei]] on October 17, 2008.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} According to the game's director, Katsura Hashino, the subtitle "Fes" is derived from the word "festival".{{cite web |author=Chris Winkler |title=Atlus Announces Persona 3 Director's Cut |url=http://www.rpgfan.com/news/2006/1585.html |publisher=RPGFan |date=December 7, 2006 |accessdate=November 22, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024123226/http://www.rpgfan.com/news/2006/1585.html |archivedate=October 24, 2007 |df=}} This version of the game was re-released as a PS2 Classic on PSN for the [[PS3]] in 2012. Players of the original Persona 3 are given the option of transferring certain data from the original version's save file, such as the player's compendium, social-related stats, and maxed Social Link items. The expansion to ''Persona 3'', in addition to adding new content to the main game (referred to as "The Journey", or "Episode Yourself" in the Japanese version), includes an epilogue to the original story titled "The Answer" ("Episode Aegis" in the Japanese version). The core gameplay of The Answer is similar to that of The Journey, although the Social Link system has been removed, and the player does not attend school. ===''Persona 3 Portable''=== {{nihongo|''Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 3 Portable''|ペルソナ3 ポータブル|Perusona Surī Pōtaburu}}, an [[Video game remake|enhanced port]] of ''Persona 3'' for the [[PlayStation Portable]], was released in Japan on November 1, 2009,{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/news/persona-3-psp-port |title=All About Persona 3's PSP Port |first=Kevin |last=Gifford |date=August 18, 2009 |accessdate=August 18, 2009 |publisher=[[1UP.com]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69aZ6NUuW?url=http://www.1up.com/news/persona-3-psp-port |archivedate=August 1, 2012 |df=}} and released in North America on July 6, 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.atlus.com/p3p/home.html |title=Official Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 3 Portable Website |accessdate=January 20, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123131338/http://www.atlus.com/p3p/home.html |archivedate=January 23, 2010 |df=}} It came out to most of Europe on April 29, 2011 and the UK on April 28, 2011. The announcement in ''[[Famitsū]]'' revealed that the player would have the option to play as a female character. This selection alters some aspects of the story: the first Persona gained by the Protagonist, Orpheus, has a different appearance; Igor's assistant in the Velvet Room, Elizabeth, can be replaced with a male equivalent named Theodore.{{cite web |url=http://www.famitsu.com/game/coming/1227161_1407.html | script-title = ja:『ペルソナ3ポータブル』謎の敵"シャドウ"に挑む特別課外活動部 |publisher=[[Famitsū]] |date=September 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 3, 2010 |language=ja |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303214723/http://www.famitsu.com/game/coming/1227161_1407.html |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |df=}} The gender choice also alters some aspects of the Social Link stories. In addition to the new playable character, there are two new [[difficulty level]]s to select from alongside the original game's three. ''Persona 3 Portable'' only includes the story of the original ''Persona 3'';[http://www.atlus.com/p3p/home.html Atlus.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123131338/http://www.atlus.com/p3p/home.html |date=January 23, 2010 }} however, general changes have been made to the plot, regardless of character choice. The game's revised battle system draws on elements added in ''Persona 3'''s successor, ''[[Persona 4]]''. In combat, the player is able to directly control every character, as an alternative to utilizing the game's artificial intelligence. The ability to guard has been added, and allies will take fatal attacks for the Protagonist, preventing his or her death. Outside of Tartarus, instead of navigating the game world by directly controlling the Protagonist, the player guides an on-screen cursor around an area, allowing interaction with characters and objects. The game includes the voice acting of the original game, although characters are not shown in the world, instead being represented by on-screen portraits. In addition, the anime [[cutscene]]s seen in the original ''Persona 3'' were replaced to feature in-game graphics.{{cite web |url=http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/Persona_3_Portable/index.html |title=RPGFan Reviews – Persona 3 Portable |publisher=RPGFan |date=December 24, 2009 |accessdate=May 3, 2010 |author=James Quentin Clark |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100708203135/http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/Persona_3_Portable/index.html |archivedate=July 8, 2010 |df=}} [[Shoji Meguro]] composed 10 new musical tracks for ''Persona 3 Portable''; with the majority of them being written for the female protagonist's playthrough. Several [[Cameo appearance|cameos]] of characters from ''Persona 4'' have been added to ''Persona 3 Portable'', including [[List of Persona 4 characters#Yukiko Amagi|Yukiko Amagi]], a playable character from ''Persona 4''.{{cite web |url=http://www.famitsu.com/game/coming/1228533_1407.html |script-title=ja:『ペルソナ3ポータブル』天城雪子が登場 |publisher=[[Famitsū]] |date=October 16, 2009 |accessdate=May 3, 2010 |language=ja |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325064558/http://www.famitsu.com/game/coming/1228533_1407.html |archivedate=March 25, 2010 |df=}} It also features a cameo from Vincent Brooks, the protagonist of ''[[Catherine (video game)|Catherine]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.siliconera.com/2010/08/18/catherines-connection-to-persona-3-portable/ |title=Catherine's Connection To Persona 3 Portable |publisher=Siliconera |date=August 18, 2010 |accessdate=December 15, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160312103341/http://www.siliconera.com/2010/08/18/catherines-connection-to-persona-3-portable/ |archivedate=March 12, 2016 |df=}} ===''Persona Q: Shadow of the Labyrinth''=== {{main|Persona Q: Shadow of the Labyrinth}} ''[[Persona Q: Shadow of the Labyrinth]]'' is a dungeon crawler RPG developed for the Nintendo 3DS. It features both the characters from ''Persona 3'' and the ones from ''Persona 4'', and also includes some gameplay elements from the ''Etrian Odyssey'' series. The ''Persona 3'' campaign starts two weeks before October 4. Just as SEES prepares to enter Tartarus that night, they are pulled into the Velvet Room and sent to a school they have never seen before. While searching the area they meet the amnesiacs Zen and Rei and the Investigation Team, the latter of whom have also been pulled into the strange school: they must now work together in order to escape. The game was released in Japan on June 5, 2014, North America on November 25, 2014 and Europe on November 28, 2014. ===''Persona 3: Dancing in Moonlight''=== A [[rhythm game]] based on the setting and characters of ''Persona 3'', ''[[Persona 3: Dancing in Moonlight]]'', was released in Japan in May 2018, and will be released worldwide in December 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2017/12/24/persona-5-dancing-star-night-persona-3-dancing-moon-night-release-japan-may-24-2018/|title=Persona 5: Dancing Star Night And Persona 3: Dancing Moon Night Release In Japan On May 24, 2018 - Siliconera|date=December 24, 2017|work=Siliconera|access-date=December 24, 2017|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171224183841/http://www.siliconera.com/2017/12/24/persona-5-dancing-star-night-persona-3-dancing-moon-night-release-japan-may-24-2018/|archivedate=December 24, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |last1=Romano |first1=Sal |title=Persona 3: Dancing in Moonlight and Persona 5: Dancing in Starlight launch December 4 in the Americas and Europe |url=https://gematsu.com/2018/08/persona-3-dancing-in-moonlight-and-persona-5-dancing-in-starlight-launch-december-4-in-the-americas-and-europe |website=Gematsu |accessdate=9 August 2018}} ==Media== ===Merchandise=== Several figurines of the characters have been produced by Kotobukiya, a Japanese collectible toy company. They include the Protagonist of the game, Aigis, Mitsuru, and Akihiko.{{cite web |url=http://www.kotobukiya.co.jp/kotobukiya/figure_pvc_p3.shtml |script-title=ja:フィギュア ペルソナ３ |publisher=Kotobukiya |accessdate=August 29, 2009 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69Wxks7VB?url=http://main.kotobukiya.co.jp/redirect.html |archivedate=July 30, 2012 |df= }} The figurines have interchangeable parts, such as an Evoker or weapon, which can be stored in the base. Alter, another Japanese company that specializes in collectibles, has also released 1:8 [[Scale model#Terminology|scale]] figurines of Elizabeth, Aigis, and Mitsuru.{{cite web |url=http://www.alter-web.jp/figure/08/10_2/index.html |title=Elizabeth – ALTER |publisher=ALTER |accessdate=October 24, 2009 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107023232/http://www.alter-web.jp/figure/08/10_2/index.html |archivedate=January 7, 2010 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.alter-web.jp/figure/07/10_1/index.html |title=Aigis – ALTER |publisher=ALTER |accessdate=November 30, 2007 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211135448/http://www.alter-web.jp/figure/07/10_1/index.html |archivedate=December 11, 2007 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.alter-web.jp/figure/08/06_2/index.html |title=Mitsuru – ALTER |publisher=ALTER |accessdate=February 1, 2008 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080127140919/http://www.alter-web.jp/figure/08/06_2/index.html |archivedate=January 27, 2008 |df= }} The headphones worn by the Protagonist are sold by Audio-Technica, model ATH-EM700(Japan-only version).{{cite web |title=Ear-Fit Headphones ATH-EM700 |url=http://www.audio-technica.co.jp/atj/sc/ath-em700/index.html |publisher=[[Audio-Technica]] |accessdate=October 4, 2009 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090917152810/http://www.audio-technica.co.jp/atj/sc/ath-em700/index.html |archivedate=September 17, 2009 |df= }} Atlus collaborated with the Japanese publishing company Enterbrain to publish the game's multiple strategy guides and an artbook detailing character and setting designs. Udon announced that they will release an English edition of [[Enterbrain]]'s ''Persona 3: Official Design Works'' artbook to be released June 10, 2012.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Persona-3-Official-Design-Works/dp/192677843X/ |title=Persona 3: Official Design Works |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |accessdate=June 28, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120701165812/http://www.amazon.com/Persona-3-Official-Design-Works/dp/192677843X |archivedate=July 1, 2012 |df=}} ===Manga=== A [[manga]] adaptation of ''Persona 3'' written and illustrated by Shūji Sogabe was published monthly in the Japanese magazine ''[[Dengeki Maoh]]'' until it went on hiatus once ''Persona 4'' was released. However, it began serialization again starting November 7, 2011, moving from ''Dengeki Maoh'' to Atlus's official ''Persona Magazine.''{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2011-10-18/monthly-persona-magazine-launches-on-november-7 |title=Monthly Persona Magazine Launches on November 7 |publisher=[[AnimeNewsNetwork]] |date=October 18, 2011 |accessdate=June 28, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122083645/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2011-10-18/monthly-persona-magazine-launches-on-november-7 |archivedate=January 22, 2012 |df=}}{{cite web |title=Persona 3 Game-Based 4-Panel Manga Serialized Online |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-01-31/persona-3-game-based-4-panel-manga-serialized-online |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=January 31, 2008 |accessdate=September 8, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519020500/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-01-31/persona-3-game-based-4-panel-manga-serialized-online |archivedate=May 19, 2015 |df=}} As of February 2017, 11 volumes have been released.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/%E3%83%9A%E3%83%AB%E3%82%BD%E3%83%8A3-11-%E9%9B%BB%E6%92%83%E3%82%B3%E3%83%9F%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF%E3%82%B9-%E6%9B%BD%E6%88%91%E9%83%A8-%E4%BF%AE%E5%8F%B8/dp/4048926853/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1503907056&sr=1-3&keywords=%E3%83%9A%E3%83%AB%E3%82%BD%E3%83%8A3|script-title=ja:ペルソナ3 11 (電撃コミックス) [コミック] |publisher=[[Amazon.co.jp]] |accessdate=February 27, 2017 |language=Japanese}} ===Anime=== {{See also|Persona: Trinity Soul|List of Persona: Trinity Soul episodes|l2=list of episodes}} A non-canonical spin-off [[anime]] to ''Persona 3'' titled ''[[Persona: Trinity Soul]]'' aired in Japan starting in January 2008 and ran for twenty-six episodes. Taking place ten years after the events of the game, the anime features Akihiko as a secondary character.{{cite web |title=Persona 3 Game Adapted as Television Anime for January |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-11-07/persona-3-game-adapted-as-television-anime |accessdate=November 7, 2007 |date=November 7, 2007 |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150412151131/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-11-07/persona-3-game-adapted-as-television-anime |archivedate=April 12, 2015 |df=}} [[NIS America]] licensed the show and released it in two half-season deluxe edition box sets with the original Japanese audio track in 2010.{{cite web |title=NIS America Goes Anime |url=http://rpgland.com/news/nis-america-goes-anime/ |publisher=RPGLand |accessdate=February 11, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121209085131/http://rpgland.com/news/nis-america-goes-anime/ |archivedate=December 9, 2012 |df=}} ===Films=== {{see also|Persona 3 The Movie: No. 1, Spring of Birth|Persona 3 The Movie: No. 2, Midsummer Knight's Dream|Persona 3 The Movie: No. 3, Falling Down|Persona 3 The Movie: No. 4, Winter of Rebirth}} In June 2012, the end of the newly released ''Persona 4'' film announced that ''Persona 3'' would receive a film series adaptation.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-06-10/persona-3-rpg-film-adaptation-confirmed |title=Persona 3 RPG's Film Adaptation Confirmed |publisher=Anime News Network |date=June 10, 2012 |accessdate=June 10, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120613172720/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-06-10/persona-3-rpg-film-adaptation-confirmed |archivedate=June 13, 2012 |df=}} It was produced by [[Anime International Company|AIC ASTA]] (first film) and [[A-1 Pictures]] (films two through four). The first film was directed by Noriaki Akitaya, the second by Tomohisa Naguchi, and the third and fourth by Keitaro Motonaga. The main Japanese voice actors from the original game reprised their roles in the film series.{{cite web |url=http://www.p3m.jp/staff/index.html |title=PERSONA 3 THE MOVIE |publisher=P3m.jp |accessdate=July 17, 2013 |language=Japanese |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150513174952/http://www.p3m.jp/staff/index.html |archivedate=May 13, 2015 |df=}} ===Radio drama=== Several series of [[Radio drama in Japan|radio dramas]] based on ''Persona 3'' and ''Persona 3: FES'' have been released in Japan. ''Persona 3 Drama CD: A Certain Day of Summer'' features an original story voiced by the game's original cast. ''Persona 3 Drama CD Vol. 2 -Moonlight-'' links the story of ''Persona 3'' and the epilogue released with ''Persona 3: FES''. From February to June 2008, a series of character dramas were released as five CDs. The volumes respectively focus on the Protagonist and Ryoji; Junpei and Chidori; Fuuka, Ken, and Aigis; Yukari and Mitsuru; and Akihiko, Shinjiro, and Koromaru. In early 2009, a two-volume side story about Mitsuru was released.

===Stage production=== {{See also|Persona 3: The Weird Masquerade}} ''Persona 3'' was adapted into five live stage musicals, with the first one performed in 2014. The series of plays were first announced in August 2013{{cite news|first=Joseph |last=Luster |url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2013/08/13-1/persona-3-the-weird-masquerade-turns-the-rpg-into-a-stage-play |title='Persona 3: The Weird Masquerade' Turns the RPG into a Stage Play |work=[[Crunchyroll]] |date=August 13, 2013 |accessdate=August 9, 2018}} and were written by Kumagai and Kotora Kagurazuka, with music by Meguro. The plays included separate shows for both the male and female protagonists, who were named Sakuya Shiomi and Kotone Shiomi, and had minor dialogue and scenes unique to each protagonist.{{cite web |url=http://www.clie.asia/p3wm_kakusei/cast.html |title=PERSONA3 -ペルソナ3-｜青の覚醒｜CAST |language=Japanese |publisher=Index Corporation |accessdate=September 4, 2017}} The plays starred [[Shouta Aoi]] as Sakuya, [[Kana Asumi]] as Kotone, Maho Tomita as Yukari, [[Genki Okawa]] as Junpei, Yuki Fujiwara as Akihiko, Asami Tano as Mitsuru, Marina Tanoue as Fuuka, [[ZAQ]] as Aigis, and Waku Sakaguchi and Tomonori Suzuki as Ken. The musicals were also broadcast live on [[Niconico]]{{cite web |url=http://blog.nicovideo.jp/niconews/ni048536.html |title=舞台「PERSONA3 the WM ～群青の迷宮～」配信決定！ |language=Japanese |publisher=Niconico |date=September 14, 2014| accessdate=December 3, 2017}} and a behind-the-scenes special aired on [[Tokyo MX]].{{cite web |url=http://s.mxtv.jp/anime/p3wm/ |title=舞台『ペルソナ3』 ～人気の秘密を暴く～｜アニメ｜TOKYO MX |language=Japanese |publisher=Tokyo MX |accessdate=December 3, 2017}} The first play, ''Persona 3: The Weird Masquerade: The Blue Awakening'' ran from January 8–12, 2014, at Theater G Rosso,{{cite web |url=http://www.clie.asia/p3wm_kakusei/stage.html |title=PERSONA3 -ペルソナ3-｜青の覚醒｜STAGE |language=Japanese |publisher=Index Corporation |accessdate=September 4, 2017}} and was given a home release on May 14, 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.clie.asia/p3wm_kakusei/other.html |title=PERSONA3 -ペルソナ3-｜青の覚醒｜OTHER |language=Japanese |publisher=Index Corporation |accessdate=September 4, 2017}} ''The Blue Awakening'' followed events up to Fuuka's inclusion into the party.{{cite web |url=http://www.clie.asia/p3wm_kakusei/about.html |title=PERSONA3 -ペルソナ3-｜青の覚醒｜ABOUT |language=Japanese |publisher=Index at Theater 1010{{cite web |url=http://www.clie.asia/p3wm_meikyu/about.php |title=PERSONA3 -ペルソナ3-｜群青の迷宮｜ABOUT |language=Japanese |publisher=Index Corporation |accessdate=September 4, 2017}}{{cite web {{primary sources|date=October 2017}} {{lowercase title}} {{Infobox software | name = pH7CMS | screenshot = PH7CMS_3.1_Screenshot_Homepage.png | caption = Screenshot of pH7CMS 3.1, splash homepage with background video enabled | screenshot alt = pH7CMS 3.1, splash homepage with background video enabled | developer = Pierre-Henry Soria | programming_language = [[PHP]], [[MySQL]], [[JavaScript]], [[HTML]], [[CSS]] | operating system = | released = {{start date and age|2010|11}}<!-- {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | latest release version = 12.6.0<ref name="ph7_release">https://ph7cms.com/ph7cms-12-6-released/</ref> | latest release date = {{start date and age|2018|05|25}} | genre = [[Social software]], [[social networking]] | status = Active | language = English, French, Dutch, Spanish, Brazilian Portuguese, Indonesian | website = {{URL|pH7CMS.com}} | license = [[GNU General Public License 3|GPL v.3]] }}
'''pH7CMS''' (formerly known as '''pH7 Social Dating CMS''') is an open source Social Dating software that allows creation of online communities and social dating services.
pH7CMS is written in PHP 5.6,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://ph7cms.com/doc/en/requirements |title=Requirements for the pH7 "Dating Community Social" software}}</ref> is object-oriented and uses the [[Model–view–controller|MVC pattern]] (Model-View-Controller).
The software is based on the homemade ''pH7Framework'' and is designed with the [[KISS principle]] in mind. For better flexibility, the software uses [[PHP Data Objects|PDO]] (PHP Data Objects) abstraction which allows the choice of the database. The principle of development is [[Don't repeat yourself|DRY]] (Don't Repeat Yourself) aimed at reducing repetition of information of all kinds (not duplicate code).
It also wants to be fast, low-resource-intensive, extremely powerful and very secure.
pH7CMS is distributed in two distinct packages. One free with less features, no update/upgrade script and only for personal sites and another one sold for commercial sites, including premium features and update/upgrade scripts.
==Improvement history==
* In pH7CMS 1.0.10, the template syntax has been totally rewritten and gives a better understanding for Web designers.<ref>[https://github.com/pH7Software/pH7-Social-Dating-CMS/blob/master/_repository/upgrade/1.0.3-1.0.10/info/config.ini pH7CMS 1.0.10 Github changelog]</ref> * pH7CMS 1.1 introduced a new hash algorithm password and uses from now the [http://php.net/manual/en/book.password.php Password Hashing API] introduced by PHP 5.5. The version also includes many bug fixes, some new features and removes the Donation plugin from the Page module. * pH7CMS 1.1.2 provide a huge improvement for the Payment module, a lot of bug fixes and a better Database Language integration.<ref>[https://github.com/pH7Software/pH7-Social-Dating-CMS/blob/master/_repository/upgrade/1.1.0-1.1.2/info/config.ini pH7CMS 1.1.2 Github changelog]</ref> * pH7CMS 1.1.8 is the last version of the 1.1 branch. * From the 1.2 version, the software has a full responsive design.<ref>[http://ph7cms.com/full-responsive-design/ pH7CMS 1.2 will come with a Full Responsive Design]</ref> * The 1.2 version is also more focus on "Dating features than the 1.0 and 1.1 branches.<ref>[http://ph7cms.com/hardworking-for-1-2-version-roadmap-overview/ Hardworking for the next 1.2 branch – Overview of the Roadmap]</ref> * Since pH7CMS 1.2, the company doesn't only provide a "dating software provider", but also a Real Social/Dating Business Solution with a support from the "dating idea startup" until the "profitable and popular online dating business". The service is mainly provided by [http://edatingmarketing.com e-Dating Marketing]. * pH7CMS 1.2.1 becomes the first dating software provider to offer Bitcoin as a payment gateway. Bitcoin is very appreciate on a dating websites because it allows people to make payments in an anonymous way.<ref>[http://ph7cms.com/dating-software-provider-to-accept-bitcoin/ First Dating Software Provider to accept Bitcoin]</ref> * pH7CMS 1.2.3 has a new module called "api" allowing to use pH7CMS as a RESTful Web app and since that version, all pH7CMS installation has a unique API key in pH7CMS config.ini file. Integration to external software/site or mobile app (such iOS & Android) is possible with minimum modification and maximum security. Better Geo recognition has also been implemented. * pH7CMS 1.2.5 has a lot of bugfixes and improvements (including a better displaying on small devices with the responsive theme) * pH7CMS 1.2.7 has been released on the 24th of December just for Christmas. It has a lot of improvements such as better banner positions increasing the click-through-rate. The benchmark visible when pH7CMS is on the [http://ph7cms.com/doc/en/how-to-set-the-development-mode development mode]. {{Proseline|date=January 2015}} '''Rhetorical modes''' (also known as '''modes of discourse''') describe the variety, conventions, and purposes of the major kinds of [[language]]-based [[communication]], particularly [[writing]] and [[speaking]]. Four of the most common rhetorical modes and their purpose are [[Narrative mode|narration]], [[description]], [[Exposition (narrative)|exposition]], and [[Argumentation theory|argumentation]].{{sfn|Rozakis|2003|p=271}} The first codification of these rhetorical modes was by Samuel P. Newman in ''A Practical System of Rhetoric'' in 1827.{{sfn|Connors|1981|p=445}}
==Narration== {{further|Exposition (narrative)}} {{Refimprove section|date=September 2014}} The purpose of [[narrative mode|narration]] is to tell a story or narrate an event or series of events. This writing mode frequently uses the tools of descriptive writing. Narration is an especially useful tool for sequencing or putting details and information into some kind of logical order, usually chronological. Working with narration helps us see clear sequences separate from all other mental functions. Examples include: *[[Anecdote]]s *[[Autobiography]] *[[Biography]] *[[Novel]]s *[[Oral history]] *[[Short story]]
==Description== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2014}} The purpose of description is to re-create, invent, or visually present a person, place, event, or action so that the reader can picture that which is being described. Descriptive writing can be found in the other rhetorical modes. Examples include: *[[Personal journal|Journal writing]] *[[Poetry]]
==Exposition== Expository writing is a type of [[writing]] where the purpose is to explain, inform, or even describe.<ref name=ball>{{cite web|last=Ball|first=Arnetha F.|title=Expository Writing|url=http://www.stanford.edu/~arnetha/expowrite/info.html|publisher=Stanford University}}</ref> It is considered to be one of the four most common rhetorical modes.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nordquist|first=Richard|title=Expository Writing|url=http://grammar.about.com/od/e/g/Expository-Writing-term.htm|publisher=About.com}}</ref>
The purpose of expository writing is to explain and analyze information by presenting an idea, relevant evidence, and appropriate discussion. In [[narrative]] contexts (such as [[history]] and [[fiction]]), [[exposition (narrative)|exposition]] provides background information to teach or entertain. In other [[nonfiction]] contexts (such as [[technical communication]]), the purpose is to teach and inform. Examples include:{{sfn|Rozakis|2003|p=271}} * Business **[[Business letter]]s **[[Report]]s **[[News release|Press releases]] * Journalism **[[How-to|How-to essays, such as recipes and other instructions]] **[[Article (publishing)|News article]] * Personal **[[Personal letter]]s **[[Will (law)|Wills]] * Academic and [[technical communication]] **[[Scientific writing]] ***[[Scientific report]]s ***[[Scientific journal]] articles **[[Academic writing]] ***[[Term paper]]s ***[[Textbook]]s ***General [[reference work]]s ****[[Encyclopedia|Encyclopedia articles]] **[[Technical writing]] ***[[User guide]]s ***[[Technical standard]]s
==Argumentation== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2014}} The purpose of argumentation (also called ''[[persuasive writing]]'') is to prove the validity of an idea, or point of view, by presenting sound reasoning, discussion, and argument to thoroughly convince the reader. Persuasive writing/Persuasion is a type of argumentation with the additional aim to urge the reader to take some form of action. Examples include: *[[Copywriting|Advertising copy]] *[[review|Critical review]] *[[Editorial]]s *[[Job evaluation]] *[[Job application]] letter *[[Letter of recommendation]] *[[Letter to the editor|Letters to the editor]] *[[Résumé]]s
Another form of persuasive rhetoric is satirical rhetoric, or using humor in order to make a point about some aspect of life or society. Perhaps the most famous example is [[Jonathan Swift]]'s "[[A Modest Proposal]]".
==Fiction-writing modes== Each [[fiction-writing mode]] has its own purposes and conventions. Agent and author Evan Marshall identifies five fiction-writing modes: action, summary, dialogue, feelings/thoughts, and background.<ref>{{harvtxt| Marshall | 1998 | pp = 143–165}}</ref> Author and writing-instructor [[Jessica Page Morrell]] lists six delivery modes for fiction-writing: action, exposition, description, dialogue, summary, and transition.<ref>{{harvtxt | Morrell | 2006 | p = 127}}</ref> Author [[Peter Selgin]] refers to ''methods'', including action, dialogue, thoughts, summary, scene, and description.<ref>{{harvtxt | Selgin | 2007 | p = 38}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Exposition (literary technique)]] *[[Fiction writing]] *[[Literature]] *[[Writing]] *[[Discourse community]]

{{rewrite|date=October 2017}} {{merge from|The Haunter of the Dark#Robert Blake|date=October 2017}} [[File:The Haunter of the Dark by Jarkko Naas.jpg|thumb|
Robert Blake]] '''Robert Harrison Blake''' is a [[fictional character]] in the [[Cthulhu Mythos]]. The character is the creation of [[H. P. Lovecraft]] and appears in his [[short story]] "[[The Haunter of the Dark]]" ([[1935 in literature|1935]]). ==Summary== In Lovecraft's tale, Robert Blake is a young author and painter from [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]]. He comes to [[Providence, Rhode Island]] and moves into an apartment on College Street. While there, he completes five short stories: "The Burrower Beneath", "The Feaster from the Stars", "In the Vale of Pnath", "Shaggai", and "The Stairs in the Crypt". He becomes obsessed with a deserted church on Federal Hill that he can see from his window. He later learns of a cult that was once active there, the [[Cthulhu Mythos cults#Church of Starry Wisdom|Church of Starry Wisdom]]. His investigation of this cult inevitably leads to his death. ==Origin== Lovecraft based Robert Blake on one of his correspondents, the teenage [[Robert Bloch]]Robert Bloch (1917–1994) is best known as the author of the novel ''[[Psycho (novel)|Psycho]]'', on which the [[Alfred Hitchcock]] film is based. who had just begun his career as a writer of [[horror fiction|horror]] and [[science fiction]]. In the story, Lovecraft even had Blake residing at Bloch's real-life address at the time: 620 E. Knapp Street, [[Milwaukee]].Pearsall, "Blake, Robert Harrison", ''The Lovecraft Lexicon'', p. 87. The development of the Blake character has a notable backstory. The character first appeared as the unnamed narrator of Bloch's "The Shambler from the Stars" ([[1935 in literature|1935]]). Before he wrote the tale, Bloch thought it would be amusing to kill off a character based on Lovecraft. Lovecraft consented to the idea and gave his permission in the form of a satirical letter, signed by Lovecraft himself and "attested" by several of his creations: [[Abdul Alhazred]], [[Cthulhu Mythos biographies#Du Nord, Gespard|Gespard du Nord]], [[Cthulhu Mythos biographies#Von Junzt, Friedrich Wilheim|Frederich von Juntz]], and the "Tcho-Tcho Lama of Leng" (possibly referring to the [[High Priest Not to Be Described]]). The body of the letter appears as follows:
This is to certify that Robert Bloch, Esq., of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, U.S.A.—reincarnation of Meinheer [[Cthulhu Mythos biographies#Prinn, Ludwig|Ludvig Prinn]], author of [[De Vermis Mysteriis]]—is fully authorised to portray, murder, annihilate, disintegrate, transfigure, metamorphose, or otherwise manhandle the undersigned in the tale entitled ''The Shambler from the Stars''.Carter, ''Lovecraft: A Look Behind the Cthulhu Mythos'', pp. 116–7.
In Bloch's story, the Lovecraft-based character becomes the ill-fated victim of an [[star vampire|invisible, vampiric monster]] summoned from the depths of outer space. Lovecraft was delighted by the story and returned the favor by killing off Robert Bloch, a.k.a. Robert Blake, in "The Haunter of the Dark".Carter, p. 120. Years later, Bloch wrote a sequel to "The Haunter of the Dark" entitled "The Shadow from the Steeple" ([[1950 in literature|1950]]) in which Robert Blake's death is investigated by his friend Edmund Fiske.Carter, p. 123. [[Robert M. Price]] believes that Robert Blake is not merely a counterpart to Robert Bloch, but is actually a combination of three different people: Bloch, Lovecraft himself, and [[Clark Ashton Smith]]. As one example, Price notes that the dwelling that Blake occupies in Providence parallels Lovecraft's own apartment. Furthermore, Blake, like Smith, is a skilled painter and produces bizarre "studies of nameless, unhuman monsters, and profoundly alien, non-terrestrial landscapes."Lovecraft, "[[The Haunter of the Dark]]", ''The Dunwich Horror and Others'', p. 94. Lovecraft sometimes mentioned Smith's art in his own stories whenever he wanted to feature a weird setting or the reproduction of one. In "The Haunter of the Dark", however, Price believes that Lovecraft took the notion one step further and depicted Smith himself as one of the three aspects of Robert Blake.Price, "The Works of Robert Blake", ''Crypt of Cthulhu #80'', p. 30. ==Short story titles== Other Mythos authors have attempted to supply text for Blake's fictional titles, perhaps writing them as Blake himself might have. Robert M. Price argues that at least three of these titles have already been written. First, "The Feaster from the Stars" is obviously a parallel to Bloch's "The Shambler from the Stars" (a title Lovecraft suggested to Bloch). Second, "The Stairs in the Crypt" appears to be a cross between two of Bloch's short stories: "The Grinning Ghoul" and "The Secret in the Crypt". Lastly, "The Burrower Beneath" is similar to "The Blasphemy Beneath", an early story that Bloch sent to Lovecraft for review.Price, "About 'The Burrower Beneath'", ''The Book of Eibon'', p. 191. Price believes that Blake's "In the Vale of Pnath" is another name for Lovecraft's ''[[The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath]]'' ([[1926 in literature|1926]]), since in the story [[Randolph Carter]] is carried to the [[Underworld (Dreamlands)|Underworld]] and soon realizes that he is "in the vale of Pnath". "Shaggai" may parallel Lovecraft's "The Whisperer in Darkness" ([[1931 in literature|1931]]). Since in "The Haunter of the Dark" Lovecraft says that [[Cthulhu Mythos celestial bodies#Shaggai|Shaggai]]For [[Ramsey Campbell]]'s take on Shaggai, see [[Insect from Shaggai]]. lies beyond Yuggoth, he is adding yet another planet to the [[solar system]], essentially a new version of Yuggoth. Since Lovecraft often repackaged his Mythos creations in the revision stories he wrote for other authors, Price believes that "Shaggai" is the kind of story that Lovecraft would have ghostwritten if "Robert Blake" had been his client.Price, "The Works of Robert Blake", p. 31. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== ===Primary sources=== * Lovecraft, Howard P. "The Haunter of the Dark (1936)" in ''The Dunwich Horror and Others'', S. T. Joshi (ed.), Sauk City, WI: Arkham House, 1984. {{ISBN|0-87054-037-8}}. Definitive version. ===Secondary sources=== ;Books * Carter, Lin. ''Lovecraft: A Look Behind the Cthulhu Mythos'', New York, NY: Ballantine Books, 1972. * Pearsall, Anthony B. ''The Lovecraft Lexicon'' (1st ed.), Tempe, AZ: New Falcon Pub., 2005. {{ISBN|1-56184-129-3}}. * Price, Robert M. "About 'The Burrower Beneath'", ''The Book of Eibon'' (1st ed.), Chaosium, Inc., 2002. {{ISBN|1-56882-129-8}}. ;Journals * {{cite journal|author=Price, Robert M.|title=The Works of Robert Blake|journal=Crypt of Cthulhu|year=[[Eastertide]] 1992|volume= 11|issue= 2}} Robert M. Price (ed.), West Warwick, RI: Necronomicon Press. ==External links== * {{Wikisource-inline|The Haunter of the Dark}} {{H. P. Lovecraft}} {{Robert Bloch}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blake, Robert Harrison}} [[Category:Mortals in the Cthulhu Mythos]] [[Category:Literary characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Milwaukee]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Rhode Island]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1935]] [[Category:Characters in short stories]]

[[File:Solomon Curve.png|thumb|right|The Solomon curve as published in [http://openlibrary.org/books/OL5932445M/Accidents_on_main_rural_highways_related_to_speed_driver_and_vehicle "Accidents on main rural highways related to speed, driver, and vehicle"]]]
The '''Solomon curve''' is a [[graphical representation]] of the collision rate of automobiles as a function of their speed compared to the average vehicle speed on the same road. The curve was based on [[research]] conducted by David Solomon in the late 1950s and published in 1964.<ref>{{cite news | first=David | last=Solomon | title=Accidents on main rural highways related to speed, driver, and vehicle | date=July 1964, Reprinted 1974 | publisher=Technical report, U.S. Department of Commerce/Bureau of Public Roads (precursor to Federal Highway Administration)| work = | pages = }}</ref> Subsequent research suggests significant biases in the Solomon study, which may cast doubt on its findings.<ref>{{cite news | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement on Rural Roads | date=July 2001 | publisher=Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/ruralspeed/RURALSPEED.PDF}}</ref>
== The original research == In 1964, Solomon researched the relationship between [[average]] [[speed]] and the [[collision]] [[Rate (mathematics)|rates]] of [[automobile]]s and plotted the results.<ref>{{cite book | last = Meyer | first = John Robert | authorlink = |author2=José A. Gómez-Ibáñez |author3=William B. Tye |author4=Clifford Winston | title = Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy | publisher = Brookings Institution Press | date = February 1999 | location = | pages = 275 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=MFhkehz-Ky0C&pg=PA257&dq=%22Solomon+curve%22 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8157-3181-8 }}</ref> While others have attempted to quantify the relationship between average speed and collision rates, Solomon's work was both "the earliest and best known".<ref name="Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement">{{cite web | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/speed/vol-1.html | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement |pages=Section 2.1 | accessdate=3-1-2009 |vauthors=Kloeden CN, McLean AJ, Moore VM, Ponte G | date=November 1997| publisher= | quote=}}</ref> Solomon conducted a comprehensive study of more than 10,000 collision-involved drivers and their vehicles and how other roadway, driver, and vehicle characteristics affect the probability of being involved in a crash.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cost-Benefit Evaluation of Large Truck- Automobile Speed Limit Differentials on Rural Interstate Highways|journal=University of Arkansas, Department of Industrial Engineering|date=November 2005|first=Steven L.|last=Johnson|author2=Naveen Pawar|volume=|issue=|pages=Page 24|id=|url=http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|format=MS Word|accessdate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051900/http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|archivedate=2011-07-27|df=}}</ref> He found that the probability of being involved in a crash per vehicle-mile as a function of on-road vehicle speeds follows a U-shaped curve with speed values around the median speed having the lowest probability of being in a crash.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Kuei-Yuan | last=Chan|author2=Steven J. Skerlos |author3=Panos Y. Papalambros | contribution=A CASE STUDY IN VEHICLE EMISSIONS REGULATIONS TO ACHIEVE AMBIENT AIR QUALITY STANDARDS| title=Proceedings of IDETC/CIE 2006| editor-first=| editor-last=| publisher=ASME| place=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania| pages=8| date=2006-09-10| id= | contribution-url=http://ode.engin.umich.edu/publications/PapalambrosPapers/2006/231.pdf| format=PDF| accessdate=2009-03-01| editors= }}</ref> Although typically called the Solomon curve, the U-shaped curve has also been referred to as the Crash Risk Curve.<ref name="Is speed killing us?">{{cite web | url=http://www.sense.bc.ca/research.htm | title=Is speed killing us? | accessdate=3-1-2009 | author=Society for Safety by Education Not Speed Enforcement | quote=}}</ref>
== Subsequent research == In 1968, Julie Cirillo conducted a similar study of 2,000 vehicles on interstate highways that addressed speed variation’s impact on crashes that involved two or more vehicles.<ref>{{cite book | last = Cirillo |first=J. A.|title = Interstate System Accident Research Study II, Interim Report II, Public Roads, 35 (3) |year = 1968|pages = 71–75 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> The Cirillo data produced a U-shaped curve similar to the Solomon curve.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cost-Benefit Evaluation of Large Truck- Automobile Speed Limit Differentials on Rural Interstate Highways|journal=University of Arkansas, Department of Industrial Engineering|date=November 2005|first=Steven L.|last=Johnson|author2=Naveen Pawar|volume=|issue=|pages=Page 25|id=|url=http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|format=MS Word|accessdate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051900/http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|archivedate=2011-07-27|df=}}</ref> The [[Research Triangle Institute]] conducted a study in 1970 where data was collected on 114 crashes involving 216 vehicles on a state highway in Indiana to address these concerns by (1) combining automated, embedded speed-monitoring stations with trained on-scene crash investigators, and (2) distinguishing data on vehicles slowing to negotiate a turn from vehicles moving slowly in the flow of traffic.<ref>Research Triangle Institute, "Speed and Accident, Volume II," Report No. FH-11-6965, National Highway Safety Bureau, June 1970.</ref> Reporting on these results in 1971, academics West and Dunn confirmed the findings of Solomon and Cirillo,<ref name="Impacts and Issues Related to Proposed Changes in Oregon’s Interstate Speed Limits">{{cite web | url=http://www.its.pdx.edu/speedlimits/final%20interstate%20speed%20review%20report%20(9.12).pdf | title=Impacts and Issues Related to Proposed Changes in Oregon’s Interstate Speed Limits | accessdate=3-1-2009 | author=Monsere, C. M., Newgard, C., Dill, J. Rufolo, A., Wemple, E., Bertini, R. L., and Milliken, C. | date=September 2004 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6H4UFKRFH?url=http://www.its.pdx.edu/speedlimits/final%20interstate%20speed%20review%20report%20%289.12%29.pdf | archivedate=2013-06-02 | df= }}</ref> but found that crashes involving turning vehicles accounted for 44 percent of all crashes observed in the study and that excluding these crashes from the analysis greatly attenuated the factors that created the U-shape of the Solomon curve.<ref>West, L. B., Jr. and Dunn, J. W. (1971). "Accidents, Speed Deviation and Speed Limits." Traffic Engineering. 41 (10), 52-55</ref>
In 1991, Fildes, Rumbold, and Leening collected self-reported crash data from 707 motorists in Australia with fewer than 200 reporting that they had been in a collision but, unlike Solomon and Cirillo, the researchers found no relationship between slower speeds and increased crash involvement.<ref name="Speed Behaviour and Drivers’ Attitude to Speeding">{{cite web | url=http://www.monash.edu.au/muarc/reports/muarc016.html | title=Speed Behaviour and Drivers’ Attitude to Speeding | accessdate=3-2-2009 |vauthors=Fildes BN, Rumbold G, Leening A | date=June 1991 | location = Monash University Accident Research Centre, Victoria Australia, | quote=}}</ref> Notwithstanding the many studies over the years, in testimony before the Ohio Senate Highways and Transportation Committee on June 10, 2003, Julie Cirillo, Former Assistant Administrator and Chief Safety Officer for the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration ([[FMCSA]]), testified that "up to the present time there has been no evidence to alter Solomon’s original finding that variance from the mean operating speed is a major contributor to accidents".<ref name="Testimonyof2003">{{cite news|title=Testimony of Julie Anna Cirillo |date=2003-06-10 |publisher=OOIDA |url=http://www.landlinemag.com/Special_Reports/2003/June03/Cirillo_Testimony.htm |work=Land Line Magazine |pages= |accessdate=2009-03-02 |language= |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040816035301/http://www.landlinemag.com/Special_Reports/2003/June03/Cirillo_Testimony.htm |archivedate=August 16, 2004 }}</ref>
In July 2001, Kloeden CN, Ponte G and McLean AJ of the Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University quantified the relationship, "... between free travelling speed and the risk of involvement in a casualty crash in 80 km/h or greater speed limit zones in rural South Australia" using a case control study design. They found, "..the risk of involvement in a casualty crash increased more than exponentially with increasing free travelling speed above the mean traffic speed and that travelling speeds below the mean traffic speed were associated with a lower risk of being involved in a casualty crash." Outlining past research in this area, they suggest that, in the Solomon research, "Both the numerator (number of crashes in a particular speed band) and the denominator (number of vehicle-miles travelled in that same speed band) may have been quite inaccurate for relatively low speeds." <ref>{{cite news | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement on Rural Roads | date=July 2001 | publisher=Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/ruralspeed/RURALSPEED.PDF}}</ref>
== Theoretical foundation == Hauer provided a theoretical foundation for the Solomon curve in 1971—“for example, if I drive at 45 mph, while the [[median]] of the pack is 60 mph, how many cars will pass me in an hour and hence have a chance to collide with me?”—that showed that the theoretical [[Frequency distribution|distribution]] was nearly identical to the Solomon curve.<ref name="Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MFhkehz-Ky0C&pg=PA276&lpg=PA276&dq=%22The+Solomon+Curve%22 | title=Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy | accessdate=3-1-2009 |author1=John Robert Meyer |author2=José A. Gómez-Ibáñez |author3=William B. Tye |author4=Clifford Winston | pages=Page 276 | isbn=978-0-8157-3181-8 | date=1999-02}}</ref>
== Practical implications == While Solomon’s research focused on speed deviation, and not speed per se, some commentators have cited Solomon’s research to support the conclusion that raw speed and crash risk are not directly related.<ref name="Is speed killing us?"/> On the other hand, while recognizing Solomon's research reveals the importance to safety of variability around average speed, Leonard Evans concludes in ''[[Traffic Safety and the Driver]]'' that control of absolute driver speed, and not variability, should be the primary focus of traffic safety regulation.<ref>{{cite book | last = Evans | first = Leonard| title = Traffic Safety and the Driver | publisher = Van Nostrand Reinhold | year = 1991 | location = New York, New York | pages = 155–56 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=OyuGJJ6rKQ0C&pg=PA155&lpg=PA155&dq=%22Traffic+Safety+and+the+Driver%22+Solomon| isbn = 0-442-00163-0 }}</ref> Both views support the fact that the seminal research underlying the Solomon curve shows that the greater the difference between a driver’s speed and the average speed of traffic—both above and below that average speed—the greater the likelihood of involvement in a crash.<ref>{{cite book | last = Transportation Research Board | first = Committee for Guidance on Setting and Enforcing Speed Limits | title = Managing Speed | publisher = National Research Council (U.S.) | year = 1998 | location = | pages = 46 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pARs53U6NAQC&pg=PA224&dq=%22drive+with+the+flow+of+traffic”+Solomon | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-309-06502-X }}</ref> Consequently, many states and safety organizations advise drivers to “drive with the flow of traffic”.<ref name="Testimonyof2003" />
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead]] * [[Automobile safety]] * [[Car accident]] * [[Design speed]] * [[Operating speed]] * [[Road-traffic safety]] * [[Speed limit]] * [[Traffic engineering (transportation)]] * [[Traffic psychology]] {{div col end}}

A '''sundress''' is a [[dress]] intended to be worn in warm weather. Typically, it is an informal or casual dress in a lightweight [[fabric]], most commonly [[cotton]], and usually loose-fitting. It is a sleeveless dress, typically with a wide neckline and thin shoulder straps. A sundress is typically worn without a layering top and is not typically worn over a blouse, sweater or t-shirt.
The sundress was popularized by [[Lilly Pulitzer]] in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite news |title= Chattanooga: Light clothes still heavy on style |author= Karen Nazor Hill|url= http://timesfreepress.com/news/2008/jun/20/chattanooga-light-clothes-still-heavy-style/|newspaper= Chattanooga Times Free Press |date= 20 June 2008|accessdate=25 June 2012|archive-url=https://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2008/jun/20/chattanooga-light-clothes-still-heavy-style/||archive-date=2018-09-02|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
==Current styles== The sundress provides a feminine look that is more comfortable than a skirt and blouse or another sort of dress.
Sundresses can be of any [[neckline]] and [[hemline]], including modest styles and a variety of patterns. It is typically sleeveless and collarless with a wide neckline and thin shoulder straps.
Sundresses can use a variety of closure types, including back [[zipper]]s, side zippers, front [[button]]s, back buttons, back ties, pullover or other closure styles.

This is a '''Timeline of [[BBC Local Radio]]'''
==1960s== * '''1962''' ** 27 June – The [[Pilkington Committee on Broadcasting]] publishes its report and recommends that the BBC should extend its activities to the creation of local radio stations in order to prevent the introduction of commercial radio. ** The BBC runs a series of closed circuit experiments in local radio from a variety of locations across England.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vX-XWODC3i8 BBC Radio Durham documentary about BBC local radio]</ref>
* '''1966''' ** A government White Paper paves the way for the launch of a small number (eight) of two-year experimental [[BBC Local Radio]] stations.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vX-XWODC3i8 BBC Radio Durham documentary about BBC local radio]</ref>
* '''1967''' ** 8 November – At 12.45pm, [[BBC Local Radio]] launches when the first station, [[BBC Radio Leicester]], starts broadcasting. ** 15 November – [[BBC Radio Sheffield]] launches. ** 22 November – [[BBC Radio Merseyside]] launches.
* '''1968''' ** 31 January – [[BBC Radio Nottingham]] launches and four days later the station hosts the UK's first ever radio phone-in.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2018/jan/28/we-need-to-talk-why-britain-loves-radio-phone-ins |title=We need to talk: why Britain loves radio phone-ins |publisher=theguardian.com |date=28 January 2018}}</ref> ** 14 February – [[BBC Radio Sussex|BBC Radio Brighton]] launches. ** 14 March – [[BBC Radio Stoke]] launches. ** 24 June – [[BBC Radio Leeds]] launches. ** 3 July – [[BBC Radio Durham]] launches.
* '''1969''' **10 July – The BBC publishes a report called "Broadcasting in the Seventies" proposing replacing regional broadcasting on [[BBC Radio 4]] with [[BBC Local Radio]]. **[[BBC Local Radio]] is made permanent after the two-year experiment is judged to have been a success.
==1970s==
* '''1970''' ** 2 January – [[BBC Radio Newcastle]] launches. ** 10 September – [[BBC Radio Manchester]] launches. ** September – [[BBC Radio Bristol]] launches. ** 6 October – [[BBC Radio London]] launches. ** 29 October – [[BBC Radio Oxford]] launches. ** 9 November – [[BBC Radio WM|BBC Radio Birmingham]] launches. ** 18 December –[[BBC Radio Kent|BBC Radio Medway]] launches. ** 31 December – [[BBC Radio Solent]] and [[BBC Tees|BBC Radio Teesside]] launch.
* '''1971''' ** 26 January – [[BBC Radio Lancashire|BBC Radio Blackburn]] launches. ** 25 February – [[BBC Radio Humberside]] launches. ** 29 April – [[BBC Radio Derby]] launches.
* '''1972''' ** 25 August – When the government restricted the BBC to twenty local radio stations, the corporation responds by closing [[BBC Radio Durham]]. Its resources are transferred to [[Carlisle]] where BBC Radio Carlisle, now [[BBC Radio Cumbria]], is formed.
* '''1973''' ** 8 October – [[BBC Local Radio]] faces competition for the first time when the UK's first [[Independent Local Radio]] station, [[LBC]], launches. ** 24 November – [[BBC Radio Cumbria|BBC Radio Carlisle]] launches.
* '''1974''' ** 1 April – [[BBC Tees|BBC Radio Teesside]] is renamed BBC Radio Cleveland.
* '''1975''' **No events.
* '''1976''' **No events.
* '''1977''' **No events.
* '''1978''' **No events.
* '''1979''' **No events.
==1980s==
* '''1980''' ** 11 September – [[BBC Radio Norfolk]] launches. ** 11 November – [[BBC Radio Lincolnshire]] launches.
* '''1981''' ** 4 July – [[BBC Radio Lancashire|BBC Radio Blackburn]] expands to cover all of [[Lancashire]] and is renamed accordingly. Also in 1981 BBC Radio Birmingham expands to cover the [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]], [[South Staffordshire]], north [[Worcestershire]] and [[north Warwickshire]] and is relaunched as [[BBC WM]].
* '''1982''' ** 15 and 16 March – [[BBC Local Radio]] starts broadcasting to the [[Channel islands]] when [[BBC Radio Guernsey]] and [[BBC Radio Jersey]] launch. ** 1 May – [[BBC Radio Cambridgeshire]] launches. ** 25 May – [[BBC Radio Cumbria|BBC Radio Carlisle]] expands to cover all of [[Cumbria]] and is renamed accordingly and as part of the expansion, [[BBC Radio Cumbria|BBC Radio Furness]] launches as an opt-out service. ** 30–31 May – [[BBC Radio York]] is given permission to provide a temporary service to cover [[Pope John Paul II]]'s visit to [[York]]. The service, which runs for just over 24 hours, operates on what will become BBC Radio York's MW frequency when the station launches next year, and is simulcast on [[BBC Radio Cleveland]], [[BBC Radio Leeds]], [[BBC Radio Humberside]] and [[BBC Radio Sheffield]]. ** 31 December – The final [[BBC Radio 4]] regional opt-out ends when the final edition of ''[[Morning Sou'West]]'' is broadcast, ahead of the launches of [[BBC Radio Devon]] and [[BBC Radio Cornwall]].
* '''1983''' ** 17 January – [[BBC Radio Devon]] and [[BBC Radio Cornwall]] launch. ** 2 July – [[BBC Radio Kent|BBC Radio Medway]] is expanded to cover all of the county of [[Kent]] and is renamed accordingly. ** 4 July – [[BBC Radio York]] launches on a permanent basis. ** 22 October – [[BBC Sussex|BBC Radio Brighton]] is expanded to cover all of the county of Sussex and is renamed accordingly.
* '''1984''' ** The BBC conducts five trials of citywide community stations in [[Greater Manchester]]. Each trial lasts for a few weeks and was on air for a few hours each day, opting out of [[BBC Radio Manchester]]. The experiment has not been repeated.
* '''1985''' ** 23 April – [[BBC Radio Shropshire]] launches. ** 24 June – [[BBC Three Counties Radio|BBC Radio Bedfordshire]] launches.
* '''1986''' ** 25 August – An early evening service of specialist music programmes launches on the BBC's four local radio stations in Yorkshire. The programmes are broadcast on weeknights between 6pm and 7.30pm. ** 5 November – [[BBC Essex]] launches.
* '''1987''' **September – The service of specialist music programmes broadcast on the BBC’s four local stations in Yorkshire is expanded. Programmes are broadcast on six nights a week (Wednesday to Monday) and the length of each programme is increased by 30 minutes. Consequently, the four stations now stay on air into the mid evening as the programmes are transmitted between 7pm and 9pm.
* '''1988''' ** 11 April – [[BBC Somerset|BBC Somerset Sound]] launches as an opt-out station from [[BBC Radio Bristol]]. ** 20 September – The [[Radio Data System]] (RDS) launches, allowing car radios to automatically retune, display station identifiers and switch to local travel news. ** 3 October – [[BBC Radio Gloucestershire]] launches. ** 7 October – [[BBC Radio London]] stops broadcasting. ** 25 October – BBC GLR launches. ** 30 October – [[BBC Asian Network|The Asian Network]] launches as a 70 hours-a-week service on the MW transmitters of [[BBC Radio Leicester]] and [[BBC WM]]. ** October – BBC GMR replaces [[BBC Radio Manchester]]. ** Regular late evening weeknight programming starts to appear on various stations. The programming tends to be regional rather than local with the same programme networked on several local stations. Consequently, stations are now starting to provide local/regional programming on weeknights until midnight. Previously all stations had ended local programming by mid-evening, handing over to [[BBC Radio 2]] until the following morning.
* '''1989''' ** 14 February – [[BBC Hereford and Worcester]] launches. ** 4 March – [[BBC Radio Wiltshire|BBC Wiltshire Sound]] launches. ** May – The [[BBC Night Network]] is launched on the BBC's six local radio stations in Yorkshire and north east England. The service broadcasts seven nights a week from 6.05pm (6pm at the weekend) until 12midnight.
==1990s== * '''1990''' ** 17 January – [[BBC Coventry & Warwickshire|BBC CWR]] launches. ** 12 April – [[BBC Radio Suffolk]] launches.
* '''1991''' ** Spring – The [[BBC Night Network]] is expanded to incorporate the BBC's four north west stations. Programmes now start an hour later, at 7.05pm (7pm at the weekend). ** 14 November – [[BBC Surrey|BBC Radio Surrey]] launches. ** [[BBC Radio Shropshire]] stops broadcasting on MW.
* '''1992''' ** 21 February – [[BBC Radio Berkshire]] launches. ** 17 April – [[BBC Radio Nottingham]] ends transmissions on one of its MW transmitters. [[BBC Tees|BBC Radio Cleveland]], [[BBC Radio Northampton]] and [[BBC Radio Oxford]] also stop broadcasting on MW.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbceng.info/Information/eid/press-releases/Engineering_Press_Releases_part1_23Mar1994_to_20Mar1989.pdf |title=BBC Engineering Press Release |date=27 November 1991}}</ref> ** The [[BBC World Service]] is now broadcast when stations are not on the air. Previously, [[BBC Radio 2]] had been heard during station downtime.
* '''1993''' ** 5 April – BBC Radio Bedfordshire expands to cover the counties of [[Buckinghamshire]] and [[Hertfordshire]] and is renamed [[BBC Three Counties Radio]]. ** 26 April – [[BBC Dorset FM]] launches as an opt-out service from [[BBC Radio Devon]]. ** Autumn – [[BBC GLR]] stops broadcasting on MW.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.amfm.org.uk/amfmnews/amfm17.html |title=AM/FM Online Edition #17: November 1993}}</ref> ** [[BBC GMR]] stops broadcasting on MW.
* '''1994''' ** 7 January – [[BBC Radio Sussex]] and [[BBC Radio Surrey]] are merged. The new station is temporarily named BBC Radio Sussex and Surrey, prior to a full relaunch as [[BBC Southern Counties Radio]]. ** 1 August – [[BBC Southern Counties Radio]] launches as the first [[BBC Local Radio]] station to adopt an all-speech format.
* '''1995''' ** [[BBC Coventry & Warwickshire|BBC CWR]] closes as a stand-alone station and becomes an opt-out of [[BBC Radio WM]]. * '''1996''' ** 9 April – [[BBC Radio Oxford]] and [[BBC Radio Berkshire]] merge to form [[BBC Thames Valley FM]]. Also in early 1996 [[BBC Dorset FM]] closes and its frequency is used to relay [[BBC Radio Solent]]. ** 4 November – The Asian Network expands into a full-time station when it increases the number of hours on air from 80 hours a week to 126 hours a week (18 hours a day). The station, which broadcasts on the MW frequencies of [[BBC Radio Leicester]] and [[BBC WM]], is renamed [[BBC Asian Network]]. Consequently, Radios Leicester and WM become FM only stations.
* '''1997''' ** 1 September – [[BBC Southern Counties Radio]] is relaunched. The all-speech format is dropped and the station reverts to a more traditional mix of music and speech. ** For a brief period in 1997, [[BBC Radio Manchester|BBC GMR]] is renamed GMR Talk.
* '''1998''' ** [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] replaces the [[BBC World Service]] as [[BBC Local Radio]]'s overnight downtime filler.
* '''1999''' **No events.
==2000s== * '''2000''' ** 14 February – [[BBC Thames Valley FM]] closes and [[BBC Radio Oxford]] and [[BBC Radio Berkshire]] relaunch as separate stations although Radio Berkshire operates as an opt-out service of Radio Oxford. ** 25 March – BBC GLR closes and is relaunched as [[BBC Radio London|BBC London Live 94.9]].
* '''2001''' ** 1 October – [[BBC London Live]] changes its name to BBC London 94.9. ** October – [[BBC Three Counties Radio]] launches opt-out programming for the county of [[Buckinghamshire]].
* '''2002''' **11 November – [[BBC Radio Swindon]] launches as an opt-out service from Wiltshire Sound which is renamed [[BBC Radio Wiltshire]].
* '''2003''' **No events.
* '''2004''' **No events.
*'''2005''' ** 3 September – [[BBC Coventry & Warwickshire]] returns as a stand-alone station.
*'''2006''' ** 3 April – BBC GMR changes its name back to [[BBC Radio Manchester]].
* '''2007''' ** 11 August – BBC Radio Cleveland is rebranded as [[BBC Tees]] due to its broadcasting area no longer being associated with the name Cleveland.
* '''2008''' **No events.
* '''2009''' ** 30 March – [[BBC Southern Counties Radio]] closes resulting in the return of [[BBC Surrey]] and [[BBC Sussex]] as stand-alone separate stations. ** 4 April – [[BBC Radio Swindon]], which had opted out of BBC Radio Wiltshire, is closed. The two stations are merged as [[BBC Wiltshire]].
==2010s== * '''2010''' **No events.
* '''2011''' **No events.
*'''2012''' **May – [[BBC Somerset]] launches as a full-time station. **17 August – A five-week trial to find out if listeners will miss or complain about the lack of AM services begins when [[BBC Radio Kent]], [[BBC Radio Lincolnshire]], [[BBC Radio Merseyside]] and [[BBC Radio Nottingham]] stop broadcasting regular programmes on medium wave.<ref>[https://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/08/bbc-local-radio-starts-switching-off-am/ BBC local radio starts switching off AM]</ref> **2 October – The BBC decides that BBC Radio Nottingham’s MW transmitter and Radio Kent’s relay at Rusthall near [[Tunbridge Wells]], will remain off-air after the BBC says that the trial switch-off attracted very few complaints from listeners.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/10/mw-switch-off-remains-at-bbc-local-radio/ |title=MW switch-off remains at BBC Local Radio |publisher=Radio Today |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=5 October 2012}}</ref>
*'''2013''' **5 January – The [[BBC Local Radio]] stations begin a new Saturday evening show titled ''[[BBC Introducing]]''. Hosted by a local presenter on each station, the programme's aim is to promote musicians from the area.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/12/new-saturday-night-show-for-bbc-locals/ |title=New Saturday night show for BBC Locals |publisher=Radio Today |date=18 December 2012 |accessdate=18 December 2012}}</ref> **7 January – The debut of the BBC's networked evening programme takes place, hosted by former [[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]] presenter Mark Forrest.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/10/mark-forrest-to-host-bbc-networked-show/ |title=Mark Forrest to host BBC networked show |publisher=Radio Today |date=4 October 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref> The show replaces all local programming, apart from local sport coverage. **8 July – After eight years, [[BBC Local Radio]] returns to [[Dorset]] when a breakfast show for the county, as an opt-out from [[BBC Radio Solent]], is launched.
*'''2014''' **No events.
*'''2015''' **3 March – Several BBC local radio stations are launched on [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]], with ten of the 40 local stations in England now broadcasting on the platform. They can be found on channels 719 to 722.<ref>{{cite news|first=Roy |last=Martin |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/03/bbc-local-radio-stations-launch-on-freeview/ |title=BBC local radio stations launch on Freeview |publisher=Radio Today |date=3 March 2015 |accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref> **6 October – After 27 years, the name [[BBC Radio London]] returns to the airwaves following a name change from BBC London 94.9.
*'''2016''' **19 February – [[BBC Radio Bristol]] stops broadcasting on MW following the sale of the land, on which the transmitter was located, to developers. **21 June – The BBC completes its roll-out of BBC Local Radio on [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]].<ref>[https://www.a516digital.com/2016/06/bbc-local-radio-to-arrive-in-all-areas.html BBC Local Radio roll-out on Freeview to complete on 21st June]</ref>
*'''2017''' **8 October – In a speech marking the 50th anniversary of local radio, The [[Director-General of the BBC]], [[Tony Hall, Baron Hall of Birkenhead|Tony Hall]], announces that the national evening show will be axed, resulting in local programming returning to weeknight evenings.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2017/local-radio BBC Media Centre Tony Hall pledges a "renaissance" for BBC local radio as the service marks its 50th anniversary]</ref>
*'''2018''' **15 January – The MW transmissions of BBC Radios Sussex, Surrey, Humberside, Wiltshire, Nottingham, Kent and Lincolnshire end and MW coverage for BBC Devon, Lancashire and Essex is reduced. Altogether a total of 13 MW transmitters are switched off.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/aboutthebbc/entries/46b21269-723b-4cfd-b8f3-fc735d09d0a3 Clifton, Keiran, 'About the BBC', 2017-08-10]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.a516digital.com/2017/08/bbc-starts-medium-wave-switch-off.html |title=BBC Starts MW Switch-off |publisher=a516digital.com |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref><ref>[https://radiotoday.co.uk/2018/01/bbc-confirms-local-radio-medium-wave-closures/ BBC confirms local radio MW switch-offs]</ref> **16 January – The death is announced of Midlands-based broadcaster [[Ed Doolan]], who presented for [[BBC WM]] and [[Free Radio Birmingham|BRMB]] in Birmingham, and who in 2004 became the first local presenter to be inducted into the [[Radio Academy Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-42701795|title=BBC presenter Ed Doolan dies aged 76|date=16 January 2018|publisher=BBC|accessdate=16 January 2018|work=BBC News}}</ref> **Summer – The BBC local stations start reintroducing local weekday evening programmes with all stations broadcasting their own evening output by the end of September.
